doc.field: Patronising Victorian Imperial exoticism at its best- there are 4 of these groups around the Albert Memorial- Asia Europe America and Africa. Sorry South America,Australia and Antarctica...there were only 4 corners available.

From the original model of the Albert Memorial, now in the Victoria and Albert Museum. The final sculpture has a camel, instead of the lion shown here.

The Buffalo is fairly correct- but the naked cowboy is a fanciful Victorian touch- as is the "Red Indian". These 4 sculptures alone were worth the cost of restoring the Albert Memorial in my view!
london 19thcentury victorian empire imperial kensington princealbert hubris albertmemorial

Kensington Gore is the location of the Royal Albert Hall (built on the site of Gore House), Royal College of Art, the Royal Geographical Society and in Kensington Gardens the Albert Memorial. Gore House, with its three-acre (12,000 mÂ²) estate, was the residence of William Wilberforce between 1808 and 1821, and was occupied by the Countess of Blessington and the Count D'Orsay from 1836 to 1849. In May 1851, the house was opened as a restaurant by the chef Alexis Soyer, who planned to cater for the Great Exhibition of 1851. After the exhibition, Gore House and its land were bought by the Royal Commissioners for the Exhibition. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiKensington_Gore" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiKensington_Gore<a>
Royal Albert Hall seen from Kensington Gore

From the life-size model for the sculpture "Courage and Cowardice" from the Duke of Wellington's tomb in Westminster Abbey, by Alfred Stevens. The model is in the Victoria and Albert Museum. This is cowardice, hiding under a shield like a tortoise.

From the life-size model for the sculpture "Truth pulling out the tongue of Falsehood" from the Duke of Wellington's tomb in Westminster Abbey, by Alfred Stevens. The model is in the Victoria and Albert Museum. Falsehood's mask has slipped off.

3 queens who look like sisters- maybe a comment on the fact that all Europe's Royal families were related to Queen Victoria !
